title: How to Make Japanese Cheesecake

parts.name: Setting up the Oven and Pans

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 400 °F (204 °C) and adjust the oven racks.
steps.description: Since the Japanese cheesecake will expand as it bakes, you'll need to remove the top oven rack. Move the remaining oven rack to the lowest setting.

steps.headline: Grease an 8 in (20 cm) springform pan and line it with parchment.
steps.description: Spray the bottom and sides of the pan with baking spray or spread a little shortening or butter inside the pan. Then cut a circle of parchment paper to fit the bottom of the pan and set the pan aside.Tip: If you don't have a springform pan, you can use a cake pan instead. Cut 2 long strips of parchment paper to lay across the bottom of the pan so they cross each other. You'll use these strips to lift the baked cheesecake out of the pan.

steps.headline: Line a baking dish with a kitchen cloth.
steps.description: Choose any baking dish that's large enough to hold the springform pan. Place a kitchen cloth across the bottom of the baking dish. This will hold the pan in place and prevent it from touching the bottom of the dish as the cheesecake bakes. The springform pan will go in the baking dish, then you'll add water to the dish to create a water bath. It's important to have the water bath supplies ready, so you can immediately put the batter in the pan and bake it before the cheesecake loses volume.

steps.headline: Microwave the cream cheese, butter, and milk for 1 1/2 minutes.
steps.description: Put 1 cup (225 g) of cream cheese into a microwave-safe bowl along with 4 tablespoons (56 g) of butter and 7 tablespoons (100 ml) of milk. Put it in the microwave and heat the ingredients until the butter melts and the cream cheese softens. Avoid melting the cream cheese because this will make the mixture too hot. You can microwave at 15-30 second intervals so that you can prevent overheating. If you don't have a microwave, heat the mixture over a double boiler.

steps.headline: Mix the cream cheese mixture until it's smooth.
steps.description: Keep mixing until the cream cheese combines with the melted butter and milk. The mixture should be creamy and thin. Mix until you don't see any lumps in the batter.

steps.headline: Whisk in the egg yolks, juice, vanilla, and half of the sugar.
steps.description: Whisk 6 egg yolks, 1 ⁄2 tablespoons (22 ml) of lemon juice, 6 tablespoons (75 g) of sugar, and 2 teaspoons (9.9 ml) of vanilla extract into the cream cheese mixture. Whisk until the yolks are incorporated.Did You Know? If the egg yolks sit on the granulated sugar without whisking them in immediately, the sugar can "burn" the egg yolks. This will cause the eggs to clump slightly which will make a lumpy cheesecake.

steps.headline: Sift cake flour, cornstarch, and salt onto the cream cheese mixture.
steps.description: Set a fine-mesh sieve over the bowl with the cream cheese mixture. Put 3/4 cup (105 g) of cake flour into the sieve along with 2 ½ tablespoons (23.5 g) of cornstarch and ¼ teaspoon (1.4 g) of salt. Shake the sieve gently so the dry ingredients fall into the bowl. If you don't have a fine-mesh sieve, you can use a hand-crank sifter. Sifting is important because it prevents a lumpy product.

steps.headline: Combine the batter until it's smooth.
steps.description: Remove the sieve and use a whisk to combine the dry ingredients with the cream cheese mixture. Keep mixing until there aren't any lumps of cake flour. Set the batter aside. At this point, the batter will be silky smooth, but thick.

steps.headline: Beat the whites in a separate bowl and add the cream of tartar.
steps.description: Put the 6 egg whites into a large, clean mixing bowl. Use a stand or hand mixer to beat the whites on medium speed until they start to foam a little. Then beat in ¼ teaspoon (1 g) of cream of tartar. It's important to use a completely clean bowl. If the bowl has any grease or the whites have even a little egg yolk in them, the whites won't whip up into peaks. The cream of tartar will stabilize the egg whites and give the egg whites more volume.

steps.headline: Add 6 tablespoons (75 g) of sugar and beat the whites until peaks form.
steps.description: Keep the mixer on medium speed and slowly add the remaining granulated sugar. Then turn the mixer speed to medium-high and beat until the egg whites are stiff and glossy. It should take about 2 minutes to beat the egg whites until they're stiff. To determine if you've beaten the whites until they have formed stiff peaks, turn off the mixer and lift a beater out of the whites. The whites should pull up and hold their shape instead of drooping over. Whisk just until the whites are stiff. Over-whisking can affect your cheesecake's fluffiness.

steps.headline: Fold the egg whites into the cream cheese mixture.
steps.description: Use a large metal spoon and scoop 1/3 of the egg whites into the bowl with the cream cheese mixture. Use a twisting motion with your wrist to cut the egg whites and fold them into the cream cheese mixture. Keep doing this until you don't see egg whites. Then fold in the rest of the egg whites. The batter should now look pale yellow in color and be light and fluffy. Folding the egg whites in will keep the volume in the batter so that the cheesecake won't be dense.

steps.headline: Spread the batter in the pan and set it in the prepared baking dish.
steps.description: Spoon the cheesecake batter into the greased springform pan that you lined with parchment paper. Then put the springform pan into the large baking dish with the kitchen towel.

steps.headline: Put the pans in the oven and pour hot water into the baking dish.
steps.description: Set the large baking dish with the springform pan in it on the lowest rack of the oven. Carefully pour enough hot water tap water to come halfway up the sides of the springform pan.Did You Know? Baking the cheesecake in a water bath will help it cook evenly so it's smooth and doesn't crack. Pour carefully so water doesn't splash onto the cheesecake batter as you're filling the baking dish.

steps.headline: Bake the cheesecake at 400 °F (204 °C) for 18 minutes.
steps.description: Once you've poured the water into the baking dish, close the oven door and set the timer. Let the cheesecake cook at a high temperature for 18 minutes.

steps.headline: Turn the temperature to 320 °F (160 °C) and bake it for 12 minutes.
steps.description: Don't open the oven door, but reduce the temperature to 320 °F (160 °C) while the cheesecake is still in it. Set the timer for 12 minutes. Avoid opening the oven door as the cheesecake bakes because this will introduce a burst of cool air into the oven, which could cause the cheesecake to fall or crack.

steps.headline: Turn off the heat and cool the cheesecake in the oven for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Once the cheesecake has baked for a total of 30 minutes, turn off the oven and open the oven door a crack. Leave the cheesecake to cool in the baking dish for 30 minutes. Cooling the cheesecake in the warm oven will actually prevent it from collapsing since you won't shock it with extreme temperature changes.

steps.headline: Remove the cheesecake from the oven and cool it to room temperature.
steps.description: Carefully lift the springform pan out of the baking dish with the hot water and set it on the counter. Let the cheesecake cool to room temperature before you remove it from the springform pan.

steps.headline: Dust the cheesecake with powdered sugar and serve it.
steps.description: Gently remove the springform pan from the cheesecake and peel away the parchment paper on the bottom. Set the cheesecake on a serving plate and dust the top with powdered sugar. Cut the cheesecake into slices and serve it. To remove the springform pan, run a clean knife between the edges of the cheesecake and the pan. Then unhinge the clips and remove the side pieces. For a decorative touch, place a paper doily on top before you sprinkle the powdered sugar over it. Then lift away the doily to reveal the lacy pattern. Refrigerate leftover cheesecake in an airtight container for up to 3 days.
